definition:
A set $S$ is *finite* if there exists a natural number $n$ and a
bijection from $S$ to $n$. Note that we are using the set theoretic
definition of natural number, under which the natural number $n$ equals
the set $\{0,1,2,\ldots,n-1\}$. If there exists such an $n$, then it is
unique, and we call $n$ the *cardinality* of $S$.

Equivalently, a set $S$ is finite if and only if there is no bijection
between $S$ and any proper subset of $S$.
